trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing universal Windows Store app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing universal Windows Store app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services as a backend data source for a Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services as a backend data source for a Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and view the changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and view the changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: The mobile service that you will create in this tutorial is a .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The mobile service that you will create in this tutorial is a .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: .NET backend enables you to use .NET languages and Visual Studio for server-side business logic in the mobile service, and you can run and debug your mobile service on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: .NET backend enables you to use .NET languages and Visual Studio for server-side business logic in the mobile service, and you can run and debug your mobile service on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the JavaScript backend version of this topic.
trans-unit.target: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the JavaScript backend version of this topic.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to connect a new mobile service to a universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to connect a new mobile service to a universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: The same steps can be used to connect a mobile service to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.
trans-unit.target: The same steps can be used to connect a mobile service to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.

trans-unit.source: To connect a mobile service to a Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see [Get started with data for Windows Phone](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-data.md).
trans-unit.target: To connect a mobile service to a Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see [Get started with data for Windows Phone](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-data.md).

trans-unit.source: If you cannot upgrade to Visual Studio Professional 2013 Update 3 or you prefer manually add your mobile service project to a Windows Store app solution, see [this version](../mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-store-dotnet-get-started-data.md) of the topic.
trans-unit.target: If you cannot upgrade to Visual Studio Professional 2013 Update 3 or you prefer manually add your mobile service project to a Windows Store app solution, see [this version](../mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-store-dotnet-get-started-data.md) of the topic.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data%2F).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data%2F).

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 (Update 3 or a later version).
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 (Update 3 or a later version).

trans-unit.source: Download the GetStartedWithData project
trans-unit.target: Download the GetStartedWithData project

trans-unit.source: Create a new mobile service from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Create a new mobile service from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the App.xaml.cs code file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder, and notice the new static field that was added to the **App** class inside a Windows Store app conditional compilation block, which looks like the following example:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the App.xaml.cs code file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder, and notice the new static field that was added to the **App** class inside a Windows Store app conditional compilation block, which looks like the following example:

trans-unit.source: This code provides access to your new mobile service in your app by using an instance of the [MobileServiceClient](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=302030) class.
trans-unit.target: This code provides access to your new mobile service in your app by using an instance of the [MobileServiceClient](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=302030) class.

trans-unit.source: The client is created by supplying the URI and the application key of the new mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The client is created by supplying the URI and the application key of the new mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This static field is available to all pages in your app.
trans-unit.target: This static field is available to all pages in your app.

trans-unit.source: 8.
trans-unit.target: 8.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Windows Phone app project, click **Add**, click **Connected Service...**, select the mobile service that you just created, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Windows Phone app project, click **Add**, click **Connected Service...**, select the mobile service that you just created, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The same code is added to the shared App.xaml.cs file, but this time within a Windows Phone app conditional compilation block.
trans-unit.target: The same code is added to the shared App.xaml.cs file, but this time within a Windows Phone app conditional compilation block.

trans-unit.source: At this point, both the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps are connected to the new mobile service.
trans-unit.target: At this point, both the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps are connected to the new mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to test the new mobile service project.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to test the new mobile service project.

trans-unit.source: Test the mobile service project locally
trans-unit.target: Test the mobile service project locally

trans-unit.source: Update the app to use the mobile service
trans-unit.target: Update the app to use the mobile service

trans-unit.source: In this section you will update the universal Windows app to use the mobile service as a backend service for the application.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will update the universal Windows app to use the mobile service as a backend service for the application.

trans-unit.source: You only need to make changes to the MainPage.xaml.cs project file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder.
trans-unit.target: You only need to make changes to the MainPage.xaml.cs project file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder.

trans-unit.source: Publish the mobile service to Azure
trans-unit.target: Publish the mobile service to Azure

trans-unit.source: Test the mobile service hosted in Azure
trans-unit.target: Test the mobile service hosted in Azure

trans-unit.source: Now we can test both versions of the universal Windows app against the mobile service hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now we can test both versions of the universal Windows app against the mobile service hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: View the data stored in the SQL Database
trans-unit.target: View the data stored in the SQL Database

trans-unit.source: This concludes the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a universal Windows app project to work with data in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a universal Windows app project to work with data in Mobile Services.

trans-unit.target: Next, consider reading up on one of these other topics:

trans-unit.target: Learn how to authenticate users of your app.

trans-unit.target: Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.
